title: binary install fails: export NUPIC_CORE_RELEASE
body:
`pip install nupic` on ubuntu is failing: 

```
Downloading/unpacking nupic.bindings==0.1.5 (from nupic)
  Downloading nupic.bindings-0.1.5.tar.gz (589kB): 589kB downloaded
  Running setup.py (path:/tmp/pip_build_root/nupic.bindings/setup.py) egg_info for package nupic.bindings
    Python Bindings directory: /tmp/pip_build_root/nupic.bindings
    NUMPY VERSION: 1.9.2
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 17, in <module>
      File "/tmp/pip_build_root/nupic.bindings/setup.py", line 534, in <module>
        raise Exception("Must provide path to nupic core release. export NUPIC_CORE_RELEASE=<path>")
    Exception: Must provide path to nupic core release. export NUPIC_CORE_RELEASE=<path>
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Python Bindings directory: /tmp/pip_build_root/nupic.bindings
NUMPY VERSION: 1.9.2
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 17, in <module>
  File "/tmp/pip_build_root/nupic.bindings/setup.py", line 534, in <module>
    raise Exception("Must provide path to nupic core release. export NUPIC_CORE_RELEASE=<path>")
Exception: Must provide path to nupic core release. export NUPIC_CORE_RELEASE=<path>
```

* Exception: Must provide path to nupic core release. export NUPIC_CORE_RELEASE=<path>
* also, I had to manually pip install numpy (nupic.bindings did not pull it in)

title: Serializable interface/abstract class
Create a Windows instance on EC2 for debugging NuPIC AppVeyor build failures
Get rid of old experiments from examples directory
body:
There are a bunch of very confusing directories in `examples/opf/experiments` and `prediction/experiments`. They use old style OPF experiment running, are not well documented, and are pretty confusing. However some of them are still used in valid tests.  

This issue is to move these experiment directories out of examples into a test-specific directory (maybe `tests/integration/nupic/data`?). We can delete any of these that aren't used in tests.

I'm also not sure about `examples/prediction/category_prediction` - is this doing anything useful? If not we should just remove the whole `examples/prediction` directory.

title: Change hello_tp.py to use temporal_memory.py
body:
The file `examples/tp/hello_tp.py` is for newbies who want to learn about temporal memory. It currently uses `TP10X2`. This issue is to port the file over to use the newer and easier to understand TemporalMemory and FastTemporalMemory. 

The language in the file should also be updated as it still refers to "temporal pooler".

title: Interface for learnable code
body:
All classes that have a `learn` boolean should inherit from this. 

Provided calls: 

```
getLearning() # bool
setLearning(newValue)
pruneLearning() # irreversible optimization that disables learning and prunes related data structures 
getDisabled() # True after prune ^^^ has been called
```

Use-case: reduce code duplication, nicer :), programmatically decide which code is "static"=non-learnig: 
`if (not isinstance(A, Learnable)) or A.getDisabled(): doCaching()` , see https://github.com/numenta/nupic/pull/2501#issuecomment-136973745

Classes in question: some encoders (AdaptiveScalar,..), SP, TP, TM, AnomalyLikelihood, Classifier, and respective Regions. 

-------------------------
CC @scottpurdy @oxtopus : Proposal like this, guys?

title: Move engine tests into nupic.core
body: Move tests from "tests/integration/nupic/engine" in numenta/nupic over to nupic.core.

title: Move nupic.bindings tests over from numenta/nupic
body: There are a bunch of tests in `tests/unit/nupic/math` that should be moved over from numenta/nupic.

title: fieldType List Not supported in swarming?
body:
Are lists still not supported?
Does anyone know a workaround?

"includedFields":[
    {
      "fieldName": "fft_R",
      "fieldType": "list"
    }

Is this wrong in a .json file?

title: Coordinate encoder speedup using cache
body:
caches encodings for Coord encoder to make it usable for streaming data (high throughput). 
I've decided not to cache only the hashes but went further and cache whole encodings for a given input. 
This is handeled through `cacheSize` param which defaults to 0 = off. 

I;ve tried `OrderedDict` or even better `cachetools` (LeastFrequentlyUsed, LeastRecentlyUsed caches) to better handle full cache (removal), but they don't cut it. (well, still faster than current, but cca 2x slower then this suggested dict-only approach), on the other hand, I have to remove "random" elements when purging cache. 

Results: 
`   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)`
new:  ` 63314    0.444    0.000    0.490    0.000 coordinate.py:114(encodeIntoArray)` ~63000x
old:  `14702    0.809    0.000   31.369    0.002 coordinate.py:114(encodeIntoArray)`   ~14000x

For serialization, I did not bother with storing a dict (maybe possible?), but just drop it, as it's only an optimization.  

Fixes #2150

title: Better documentation for Coordinate encoder - radius and SDRs
body:
Q1: 
I'd like to know better documentation of `radius` param in CoordinateEncoder, 
https://github.com/numenta/nupic/blob/master/nupic/encoders/coordinate.py#L104
esp. its relation to "similarity/overlap" and performance, see 

> One case where the cache would not be good for the CoordinateEncoder is when it is set up to have fine-grained resolution with a large radius. In these cases, the input coordinates may very rarely match exactly and the large radius ensures that the encodings still have overlap for similar, but not exact, coordinates. In this case the caching mechanism would just slow the function down. I don't know if normal use cases would have high cache hit rates or not but perhaps @chetan51 has an intuition for it?

from https://github.com/numenta/nupic/pull/2501#issuecomment-136948362

Q2:
The other thing is its "SDR" output - what is the quality of such a SDR? The theory says it's possible to merge SDRs to obtain a "semantic union" of them. When I asked this on the ML, I was advised this may not work. So is the output of coordinate supposed to go directly to a temporal memory, or it needs to pass through a SP (to create a better quality SDR)? (for what sizes of `w,n,radius`?)

EDIT:
Q3:
(If answer to Q2 is "use SP", maybe even if not:) What is the advantage of using a coordinate encoder instead of a `MultiEncoder` with scalars (and then SP)?

title: Add separate Dockerfile to support swarming
body: This would be similar in spirit to the official rabbitmq images in which you can specify "-management" suffix to the image tag that enables the management console for the given version (see https://github.com/docker-library/rabbitmq/blob/bb91e64b5664a4ab5cd681b7501a2830edbe9ddf/management/Dockerfile and https://hub.docker.com/_/rabbitmq/ for details). In our case, we'd add a new Dockerfile that builds off of the official nupic image, which adds mysql.

title: Compute interface
body:
Functionality: unify all that process bottom-up input (`compute()`, `encode()`), allow to change type of buffers passed around, in future place to handle multi-threading

Classes: Encoder, SP, TP, TM, Anomaly, ..?

API:
```
class Computable:
  def compute(inp)
    """
    @param inp - input as a tuple of objects
    @return we pass by return value, so some object
    """
 # maybe these?
  def getAcceptedInput():
    """exampe of input (size, type) accepted by this instance of Computable"""
    #eg: return numpy.zeros(self.getWidth())
  def getAcceptedOutput():
    return 0.0
  # ^^^ these will replace getInput/Output dimensions and getInput/OutputType, 
  # useful for mock testing
  # could save some allocation time if done properly: eg init self._acceptedIN = [...], and the use deepcopy

  def _allocateFnInp():
    """
    easily switch from using ndarrays to list, some bitmap library, ...useful for "nupic.fast forks"
    @return a fn
   """
   return numpy.array
  def _allocateFnOut():
    return float
```

Idea 2: computable for only stackable (can be interchanged) objects, input & output is a SDR, improve compute type
```
class StackableCompute(Compute):

  def compute(inp) # ndarray
    """@return ndarray"""
```

title: stricter API through interfaces
body:
Discuss on: http://lists.numenta.org/pipermail/nupic-hackers_lists.numenta.org/2015-September/004179.html

**Goal**: create interfaces for common functionality, thus enforcing same "API" calls (method name, params) and allow inheritance and polymorphism be used in code. 

**TODO**: ongoing effort, please help suggest places where this could be used.

To add a new sub-issue, please include:
```
 * API calls (methods)
 * functionality ("all objects that can learn/update their state")
 * Affected classes: where in code it applies ("SP,TP") 
```

**Issues**: 

* * *

- [ ] [Learnable](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2537)
- [ ] [Serializable](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2538)
- [ ] [Computable](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2539)

title: Re-use Connections class in SpatialPooler class
body:
In order to simplify/standardize current spatial and temporal implementations and ease future changes, I think it's very insteresting we implement Connections class (brought by @chetan51 in the new TemporalMemory) in SpatialPooler class. This already was done nicely in htm.java by @cogmission and it seems that works fine. We would move such class into a `connections.py` file and make TemporalMemory and SpatialPooler import it.

Connections class in Java:
https://github.com/numenta/htm.java/blob/master/src/main/java/org/numenta/nupic/Connections.java

SpatialPooler class in Java re-using connections:
https://github.com/numenta/htm.java/blob/master/src/main/java/org/numenta/nupic/research/SpatialPooler.java#L73

TemporalMemory class in Java re-using connections:
https://github.com/numenta/htm.java/blob/master/src/main/java/org/numenta/nupic/research/TemporalMemory.java#L67

@chetan51 @cogmission

title: TPRegion should output 2 new fields: active & predicted columns separately
body:
Depends on https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/1450

It will be useful if the output of the TP region provided separate fields for the `active` & `predicted` columns; 

currently these are combined to the default output as defined by the TP outputType - either of them, or both. 

Use case: AnomalyRegion could depend only on TPRegion (and not SP, which is now required to get the active columns, [see](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/blob/master/examples/network/network_api_demo.py#L158) ), I wonder if the [lrnActiveCells](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/blob/master/nupic/regions/TPRegion.py#L576) is the same as activeOut suggested for this usecase (maybe not, as it's only used in `learn` phase)

TODO:
- [ ] TPRegion.output provides new activeOut and predictedOut fields
- [ ] also we should remove [anomalyScore](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/blob/master/nupic/regions/TPRegion.py#L568) from TPRegion, SPRegion output, and use AnomalyRegion only

title: Speed up CoordinateEncoder for streaming data
body:
hey all, 
it would be awesome if we could speed up coordinate encoder something like `60x+` :man_with_turban: 

Use case: 
I have real world date where `3+s` ~ `600k+ data points`, but just processing with coordinate encoder takes `180+s`. 

Here's the profile:
```
        128703788 function calls (128701858 primitive calls) in 189.398 seconds

   Ordered by: cumulative time

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
        1    0.497    0.497  189.399  189.399 retina.py:1(<module>)
   663257    0.393    0.000  182.238    0.000 retina.py:170(run)
   389924    2.433    0.000  181.845    0.000 retina.py:47(encode)
   389924    1.597    0.000  178.010    0.000 retina.py:25(encodeIntoArray)
   389924    7.379    0.000  175.725    0.000 coordinate.py:100(encodeIntoArray)
  3509316    4.033    0.000  106.439    0.000 coordinate.py:112(<lambda>)
  3509316    9.117    0.000  102.406    0.000 coordinate.py:174(_bitForCoordinate)
  7018632   21.687    0.000   98.697    0.000 coordinate.py:151(_hashCoordinate)
  7019198   13.218    0.000   66.038    0.000 {method 'join' of 'str' objects}
   389924    6.516    0.000   56.352    0.000 coordinate.py:134(_topWCoordinates)
 21055896   22.783    0.000   52.819    0.000 coordinate.py:154(<genexpr>)
  3509316    7.557    0.000   46.932    0.000 coordinate.py:160(_orderForCoordinate)
  7018632    7.489    0.000   30.036    0.000 numeric.py:1681(array_str)
  7018635   14.164    0.000   27.245    0.000 math.py:5978(__init__)
  7018632   18.718    0.000   22.547    0.000 arrayprint.py:343(array2string)
  7018635   13.082    0.000   13.082    0.000 {_math.new_Random}
  7018633    6.228    0.000    6.228    0.000 {_hashlib.openssl_md5}
        1    0.012    0.012    5.005    5.005 spatial_pooler.py:52(__init__)
```

Limitations:
The task has some preconditions, which hopefully could be exploited! 
- it's `2D`, ranges on axis are small (1..127)

What do you think, should I try, or start from somewhere else completely?

title: Windows Python support
body:
This super issue covers the concerted effort to get NuPIC Python and C++ working on Windows.

Relocation of the [SWIG](http://www.swig.org/) wrapper and bindings, has isolated remaining Windows Python porting tasks to this Core library. 

In summary, these two goals need to be achieved -
1. Automated NuPIC build systems can download and bind to all versions of the core library.
2. The Windows NuPIC Core deployment package is compatible with Windows NuPIC.

Relates to "Windows binary build and deployment" https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/1786

* * *

The currently planned route forward is;
- [ ] **1.** [Finish the current C++ extension work.](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/566)
- [ ] **2.** [Python 3.5 support for Windows only, with 2.7 for all other OS.](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/567)
- [ ] **3.** [MinGW GCC and/or LLVM clang support.](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/568)

All items rely on SWIG and binding work being complete, or close to. With the first item requiring A few more days to wrangle the build, and determine whether this is a dead-end. 

The second route has some uncertainty over how long 3.5 support in a 2.7 code base will take. The Core library is virtually ready. And with Austin's investigation we should be able to judge how long this could be. Only 2to3 and six changes in NuPIC Python?  Uncertainty over 2to3 timing and ongoing support. Existing installed 3.x Python needs rebuilding with VS2015? Code review changes?  

The third item tries a more recent TDM-GCC package with script ideas from https://github.com/develersrl/gccwinbinaries  This should be a simple change to the Core lib building. Will need Travis and AppVeyor scripts and Yaml updating, taking into account CI automated build limits (40 mins maximum on AppVeyor). It didn't take too long, before the C++11 adoption, to update the Core and NuPIC to use the correct VC compiler and Window's SDK. Getting to a point of needing MySQL setup properly for some of the tests. Adding the compiler is straight forward, adding the appropriate SDK may take longer. Similar to route 1 there may still be issues and a possible need to build and supply Python from source.

* * *

A C++0X compiled Core library can be used with Python 2.7 (x64), as was demonstrated a while back https://gist.github.com/rcrowder/5fd1e964bf1bd6881c34 But with the adoption of more C++11 language features, there became a need to use more recent Visual C compilers. But doing so broke the ability to compiler extensions for Python 2.7 on Windows.

It looks possible to use various tricks and tweaks to get a build working using a mix of compilers and SDKs. But first see Piotr Dobrogost reply here http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3047542/building-lxml-for-python-2-7-on-windows/5122521#5122521 and a more detailed discussion here http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2484511/can-i-use-visual-studio-2010s-c-compiler-with-visual-studio-2008s-c-runtim?lq=1

Most seem to advocate dropping language features to use older compilers, moving away from certain C++11 features. That is possible but impracticable for NuPIC. Adding support for GCC and clang seems a likely next route to take. Visual C compilers have been lagging behind with certain C++11 features, with clang having the most features covered (so a favorite to move to over MinGW/Cygwin GCC). An alternative answer within the former linked SO article replies, is to look into Cython extensions. A risky task of unknown size.

With the release of Python 3.5 seeing support for Visual Studio 2015, that opens a route that would solve this issue. But could lead to trying to adapt to 3.x only, or have mixed support of 2.7 and 3.x! (split repos?). Microsoft's efforts of late to support Python within the Visual Studio IDE do look great thou. https://www.visualstudio.com/en-us/features/python-vs.aspx https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLReL099Y5nRdLgGAdrb_YeTdEnd23s6Ff

Alternative Python packages exists such as WinPython, Anaconda, Python(x,y), etc. Most, if not all, relying on older 2010 or 2013 compiler versions. NuPIC Core relies on Visual Studio 2015, and the latest Visual C compilers, and so has similar build issues to what we currently face.

**TODO** -Format this super-issue and arrange sub-issues. Labels, Milestone, Assignees, Feedback, Guidelines and Markdown.

title: Python 3.5 support for Windows (only)
body:
This follows on from Austin's investigation into the use of 2to3 and six with the NuPIC Python 2.7 code base. Morphing into a task to complete this work and add Python 3.5 Windows only support.

Investigation can be traced through the following;
- ~~[Update codebase to be Python 3.x compatible, while maintaining Python 2.7.x support](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/pull/2377)~~
- [Testers, Reviewers wanted re: Python3](http://lists.numenta.org/pipermail/nupic-hackers_lists.numenta.org/2015-August/003900.html)
- [Austin's 2to3 NuPIC branch](https://github.com/oxtopus/nupic/tree/2to3)

title: nupic.bindings must support standalone source builds
body: The nupic.bindings build currently relies on some previous steps to build the C++ static libraries. We need to add these steps and the appropriate files to the source build of nupic.bindings to enable source builds from the egg or via PyPI.

title: TemporalMemory  "predictedSegmentDecrement" Documentation
body:
@rhyolight @chetan51 @subutai @scottpurdy 

The documentation of "predictedSegmentDecrement" on line:
https://github.com/numenta/nupic/blob/master/nupic/research/temporal_memory.py#L68

...must be changed to reflect new findings by @ywcui1990 regarding the magnitude of the setting. "0.0004" at 2% of the column-level sparsity was found to be ineffective...

```Python
Notes:

predictedSegmentDecrement: A good value is just a bit larger than
(the column-level sparsity * permanenceIncrement). So, if column-level
sparsity is 2% and permanenceIncrement is 0.01, this parameter should be
something like 4% * 0.01 = 0.0004).
```

Should be changed. 

Please see: https://github.com/numenta/nupic/pull/2507 for the reason why this is now invalid

title: Remove build dependency on darwin64, linux64 repos
body: Completely remove all dependencies within our build systems for https://github.com/numenta/nupic-linux64 and https://github.com/numenta/nupic-darwin64

title: Allow unittests to fail after timeout & continue on error to complete
body:
I'm having troubles with the issue https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2148 
where unittests on my local installation get stuck on some serialization tests. 

Is there a way to: 
- [ ] fail some test after a certain timeout (say 120s)? 
- [x] continue the tests patrol even on failures and report the summary of failed, succeeded tests? 

This is on the contrary to what we want on Travis (fast failover) but would be useful for local issues. 

eg. `./scripts/run_nupic_tests -u -timeout=120 -continueOnError=1`

title: Add coverage for Python tests
body: There are Python tests in nupic.bindings. They will be run starting with #579 but we should hook up the coverage.

title: NuPIC build cannot find py_region_test
body:
As of https://github.com/numenta/nupic/pull/2500, NuPIC builds are failing with the latest `nupic.core`. See https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/compare/57a614d73e65aa4fa2e7d249185069b519311b09...fc056adc2e7139cc5e9218145e7472b7cca3f1b0 for the complete `nupic.core` diff. 

All Travis builds are failing with the same error:

    ./ci/travis/script-run-tests.sh: line 28: /home/travis/build/numenta/nupic/bin/py_region_test: No such file or directory

title: Hypersearch Decoupling Milestone 1: Separate swarming code into core Hypersearch files and NuPIC-specific Client
body:
The Hypersearch API should be defined in such a way that a wide variety of clients can make use of the library in domain-specific ways (e.g. a NuPIC specific client, etc. ) The NuPIC-client will continue to reside within NuPIC, making API calls as appropriate from the hypersearch framework. Hypersearch should not depend at all on anything outside of hypersearch ( besides the standard library). The NuPIC-client can depend on Hypersearch as well as NuPIC. 

Sub-issues associated with this milestone:
- [x] [Error Codes] (https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2390)
- [x] [Utils] (https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2392)
- [x] [DictUtils] (https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2403)
- [x] [ExperimentUtils] (https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2416)
- [x] [Sorted JSON Dump Migration] (https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2421)
- [x] [JSON Helpers] (https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2424)
- [x] [Resolved ExtendedLogger Dependency] (https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2426)

title: Installation from nupic.bindings binary wheel causes crash (EXC_BAD_INSTRUCTION)
body:
Platform: *OS X 10.10*
Installation: `pip install nupic`

When a user installs NuPIC with `pip install nupic`, the `nupic.bindings` module is installed from a binary wheel on pypi:

```
Collecting nupic.bindings==0.1.5 (from nupic)
  Downloading nupic.bindings-0.1.5-cp27-none-macosx_10_9_intel.whl (4.9MB)
```

When a user builds from source code with `python setup.py install`, the `nupic.bindings` module is installed from an egg file:

```
Best match: nupic.bindings 0.1.5
Processing nupic.bindings-0.1.5-py2.7-macosx-10.9-intel.egg
creating /Users/mtaylor/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/nupic.bindings-0.1.5-py2.7-macosx-10.9-intel.egg
Extracting nupic.bindings-0.1.5-py2.7-macosx-10.9-intel.egg to /Users/mtaylor/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages
Adding nupic.bindings 0.1.5 to easy-install.pth file

Installed /Users/mtaylor/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/nupic.bindings-0.1.5-py2.7-macosx-10.9-intel.egg
```

The first case above (`nupic.bindings` installed from binary wheel) causes a crash:

```

Exception Type:        EXC_BAD_INSTRUCTION (SIGILL)

Thread 0 Crashed:: Dispatch queue: com.apple.main-thread
0   _engine_internal.so          0x000000010f346d2e void std::__1::vector<std::__1::pair<std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> >, nupic::OutputSpec>, std::__1::allocator<std::__1::pair<std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> >, nupic::OutputSpec> > >::__push_back_slow_path<std::__1::pair<std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> >, nupic::OutputSpec> >(std::__1::pair<std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> >, nupic::OutputSpec>&&) + 366
```

title: Hyper search state
body:
Skeleton for HypersearchState. @scottpurdy 
Fixes #2494

title: Enables converting capnp builders/readers to pycapnp versions
body:
Adds CapnpToPyCapnp files generated from Cython and modified to exclude
a bunch of code that isn't needed. Additionally adds PyRegion writing
and PyRegionProto to wrap an AnyPointer in a known type to convert to a
DynamicStruct that gets converted into a Pycapnp PyObject that can be
passed to Python. Had to change some py::Instance methods to be const
but doesn't seem to cause issues.

fixes #545

@oxtopus please review

Replaced original NuPIC issues; https://github.com/numenta/nupic/pull/2334

title: Flexible Network Configuration
body:
This includes examples of creating different network topologies, helper scripts for creating common network configurations, and cleaning up the Network API interface so that e.g. the input/output names are more descriptive. This is important for user extensibility.

* * *

Please create sub-tasks below using this pattern:

- [ ] [Evaluate current network API and examples, and determine work to be done](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2203)
- [ ] [TPRegion should output 2 new fields: active & predicted columns separately ](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2081)

title: Improve Readability of Python algorithms
body:
This is a super issue for any initiatives that can improve the readability of our HTM implementation in Python (NuPIC).

* * * 

- [ ] [Make TemporalMemory more readable](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2496)
- [ ] [Re-use Connections class in SpatialPooler class](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/1903)

title: Implement HyperSearchState Interface
body: Implement a module for storing the state of hypersearch runs. This will be an abstract class that will be generic enough so that more case-specific state-storing methods (e.g. using a DB or writing to disk) can be implemented easily.

title: Review installation instructions for local builds of nupic.core / nupic
body: Make sure they work, are up to date, relevant, etc.

title: Code Hygiene and Tooling
body:
There are really useful tools for ensuring code quality that we don't have integrated. Things like include-what-you-use and misc. static analysis tools for both C++ and Python. This is really important for developer productivity.

* * *

Please create sub-tasks below using this pattern:

- [ ] Document using a C++ lint tool (one of splint, cppcheck, cpplint, etc)
- [ ] Document C++ memory leak checking with Valgrind
- [ ] Document using include-what-you-use with C++ files
- [ ] Switch over to enum34 - #2120 
- [ ] Move tests into Python package - #2118 
- [ ] Document Python linting with Pylint (see https://github.com/numenta/nupic/blob/master/pylintrc)
- [ ] Look into other static analysis tools for Python, checking things like circular dependencies ([yapf](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/yapf), cheesecake, [prospector](https://www.landscape.io/prospector-python-static-analysis-for-humans.html), etc)
- [ ] Look into [evsrc](http://ergoso.me/computer/science/github/software/evolutionary/couplings/2014/12/10/evsrc-evolutionary-couplings-reveal-poor-software-design.html)
- [ ] Update documentation for core C++ API
- [ ] Update documentation for core Python API
- [ ] Eliminate all warnings from nupic.core

body:
Just like we build and deploy NuPIC binaries for OS X and Linux, we should do the same for Windows. 

* * *

- [ ] [Windows Python support](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/553) (`nupic.core`)
- [ ] [Appveyor build creates nupic.bindings binary files and uploads them to S3 for iterative builds](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/570) (`nupic.core`)
- [ ] [Appveyor build configured to download nupic.bindings from S3](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/issues/2488)

- [ ] [Create a release process to deploy nupic.bindings to pypi for Windows](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/571) (`nupic.core`)

title: Create a release process to deploy nupic.bindings to pypi for Windows
body: Depends on #570.

title: Appveyor build configured to download nupic.bindings from S3
body:
The C++ extension exists in `nupic.bindings`, a pip package that should exist on S3. This can be installed with `pip install <URI to binary file>`.

Depends on https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/570.

title: Appveyor build creates nupic.bindings binary files and uploads them to S3 for iterative builds
body:
NuPIC needs `nupic.bindings` binaries for easy installation in Python. These need to be uploaded to S3 so the NuPIC iterative builds can install them (as well as developers). 

Depends on #553.

title: Finish the current C++ extension work
body:
A few days to complete this task. To determine whether Visual Studio 2015 can be used to build C++ extensions (via SWIG) for NuPIC (Python 2.7 x64). All indications point to issues with C++ language features and incompatible C run time libraries.

Latest AppVeyor progress; https://ci.appveyor.com/project/rcrowder/nupic-core-q6voj

c:\projects\nupic-core\external\common\include\capnp\schema.h(30): fatal error C1189: #error:  "Reflection APIs, including this header, are not available in lite mode."  Even though LITE mode is forced to be active.

title: Destroy Segment on its Last Synapse Deletion
body: Currently the synapses are "culled" when their permanences are decremented below a known setting so that the HTM can adapt to a totally new set of inputs and readjust itself. When the last Synapse is destroyed, the Segment should be deleted also in order to increase performance and memory associated with the obsolete Segment. There are loops which are governed by the number of segments on a cell which will benefit from a decrease in their iterative content, so these need to be destroyed along with the last Synapse.

title: TM: Synapse Creation on every permanence adjustment
body:
Not sure about what is going on with Python but I noticed something that could have tremendous memory pressure and performance impact if I'm right about what I'm seeing...?


In connections.py https://github.com/numenta/nupic/blob/master/nupic/research/connections.py#L194


``` Python
def updateSynapsePermanence(self, synapse, permanence):
    """
    Updates the permanence for a synapse.

    @param synapse    (int)   Synapse index
    @param permanence (float) New permanence
    """
    self._validatePermanence(permanence)

    data = self._synapses[synapse]
    newData = SynapseData(data.segment,   <--------------------   HERE
                          data.presynapticCell,
                          permanence)
    self._synapses[synapse] = newData

    # Update indexes
    self._synapsesForPresynapticCell[newData.presynapticCell][synapse] = newData
```

Every time the permanence is adjusted on a Synapse, a new SynapseData object is created?

(the line starting with: "newData = SynapseData(...)" )

When running a simple test in a short lived method such as extensive_temporal_memory_test.py I count something upwards of around 700 thousand Synapses! ...and 60 thousand Segments!

This line is called from "adaptSegment()" (line ~617) - EVERY TIME ADAPT SEGMENT IS CALLED!

I'm not sure how good the garbage collection is in Python (or even if it has garbage collection), but  this data should be indexed in a map and not created upon every adjustment in my opinion?

This needs to be a mutation instead of creation...?

title: setup.py not properly distinguishing source, build, and install locations
body:
There are a bunch of odd things with the build that need to be fixed.

- The `.i` and generated `.cxx` files get installed in regular non-develop builds which should be avoided
- The <repo>/build directory is created (even when a different install location is specified) and some build artifacts are copied there. But it doesn't seem to serve any purpose. We should remove it as we don't want any arbitrary hard-coded locations in our setup.py file. And it shouldn't be necessary since setuptools should automatically create a temp dir for intermediate steps
- The `.capnp` files are not included in the specified installation location. They are getting moved to the hard-coded `build/...` location
- Build artifacts like the `.so` files are copied into the source tree as well as the installation location. They should only be copied to the installation location (or the repo location if it is a developer build?)
- In develop mode, a nupic.egg-link file specifies the repo location. In this case, all generated files or files from nupic.core must be copied to the repo location or additionally need to be included in the `.egg-link` file.

Relates to #1670 
CC @rhyolight @oxtopus @david-ragazzi

title: Port python TM to C++, using C++ Connections data structure
body:
The python temporal memory implementation is located [here](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/blob/master/nupic/research/temporal_memory.py), and a subclass of it that uses the C++ Connections data structure is located [here](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/blob/master/nupic/research/fast_temporal_memory.py). Unit tests are located [here](https://github.com/numenta/nupic/blob/master/tests/unit/nupic/research/temporal_memory_test.py).

This task is to port the above implementation to C++, so that we have a pure C++ version that uses the Connections data structure.

* * *

- [x] [Create logical C++ API](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/411)
- [ ] [Map C++ API to Python API in SWiG](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/414)
- [x] [Port existing Python unit tests to C++](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/415)
- [x] [Ensure random number generation is consistent between Python / C++](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/416)
- [x] [Implement Capnp serialization configuration for TM](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/418)
- [ ] [Run exact same python test code run against C++ TM algorithm](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/419)
- [ ] [Investigate optimizations on C++ TM code](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/417)
- [x] [Add TM constructor parameter checks](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/504)
- [x] [TM unit test testWrite function completion](https://github.com/numenta/nupic.core/issues/505)

title: Remove release deployment to S3 for Linux builds
body:
Now that all the C++ is moved to `nupic.core`, we are no longer building platform-specific wheels for the `nupic` module. The logic that uploads wheels to S3 for linux platforms can be removed, and the S3 bucket emptied. 

Also, the README needs to be updated to reflect this.
